acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 1 from 48 hours EC50=1.1microg/L of the crustacea (Daphnia magna) (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data, 2004).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the absence of mortality at the highest dose of 4,000mg/kg observed in the dermal studies with rats (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1987)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists
acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.rationale: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation exposure) value of 0.109mg/L representing the lower of the two testing data, 0.109mg/L and 0.173mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data, 1993).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is a solid according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the LD50 values of 40mg/kg and 48mg/kg reported in the two oral studies with rats (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1987)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: There was no treatment-related evidence of tumor incidence observed in carcinogenicity studies in rats and mice, reported in Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1987). Also due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category C by EPA (1993).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Although acute toxicity is Category 1 and bio-accumulation is low (log Kow=2.2(PHYSPROP Database, 2005)), since there was no rapidly degrading (BIOWIN), it was classified into Category 1.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data on the substances with melting points of <55degC (melting point: 40.0-40.9degC, Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (2003)).

explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on negative data on in vitro reverse mutation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1987)), in vitro chromosome aberration tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1990)) and in vivo micronucleus tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1987)).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though being organic compounds containing oxygen (but not chlorine and fluorine) bound to the elements other than carbon and hydrogen

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Considered non-pyrophoric when in contact with air at ordinary temperatures since the substance is stable to heat (up to 150degC) (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (2003))

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Based on the evidence of reduced mating frequency and reduced pup viability at doses producing adverse effects on parental animals observed in rat 2-generation reproduction studies (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1987)).

self_heating_substances.rationale: Stable to heat (up to 150degC) (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (2003))

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1987)): "The affected animals exhibited a Draize score of 3 or greater and were not fully recovered on day 7."

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the evidence of only mild irritation (mean Draize score of 1.2), with effects fully clearing after 72 hours, observed in rabbit skin irritation studies (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1987)), that suggests little potential for skin irritation.

skin_sensitizer.rationale: Based on no evidence of sensitization in guinea pig sensitization studies (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1987)).

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Stable to water (water solubility: 200mg/L (25degC), Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (2003))

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (liver)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the evidence from animal studies including increased liver enzyme activity and intrahepatic cholestasis (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1992)). These effects were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the evidence from animal studies: in rat acute oral studies, clinical signs and symptoms including reduced motor activity, generalized convulsions, salivation and tremors were found. In mouse acute oral studies, symptoms including reduced motor activity, generalized convulsions, salivation, staggering and vomiting were noted (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1987)). These effects were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.
